structure.comment: When translating stuff like masterdata, the "contextId" is the actual id of the masterdata entry. The "term" is the field we want to translate (e.g. name by default, but in the future we might want to translate description etc
structure.name: translationTerm

field.comment: The actual term to be translated
field.name: term

field.comment: A short descriptive display name for the term.
field.name: label

field.comment: A general description of this term, it can be multi-line
field.name: description

field.comment: The default value is often the term itself, but there might be another default value
field.name: defaultValue

field.comment: You can create synonyms, for example if multiple terms actually mean the same.This could be down to copy differences or for example masterdata which can usually be identified by both the id and name.From the translating perspective, you need to know both
field.name: synonymousToId

field.comment: The environment it was created in
field.name: environmentId

field.comment: You can lock a term to prevent further translation
field.name: locked

field.comment: You can deprecate a term for future removal
field.name: deprecated

field.comment: For instance a masterdata id to indicate this is a translation for that. Or an operational instance of something like faq.
field.name: instanceId

field.comment: Whether or not this is an operational translation. If operationl, you can use the context id to store any identifier you need.
field.name: operational

field.comment: You can choose one of the default languages to set on this term if it is indeed already in a language
field.name: translationLanguageId
